title: Monday, 13th May 2019
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
JP11:04am

Morning all.

Blank canvas good morning all
Soundbuy Morning
nightingale20201 morning all
JP11:05am

Welcome to Markets Live. FT Alphaville's thing with the thing about things that sometimes go up.

Are we there yet Happy Monday
JP11:05am

And shock horror.

11:05 am
JP11:05am

Sometimes go down.

Blank canvas Did BE miss the last taxi to Bracken House?
Izabella Kaminska Hello there. I’m on RHS for a bit because I forgot my computer

BE is away this week, no doubt expanding his buy-to-let empire, so I'll be hosting mainly. With help from the rest of the Alphaville team.

JP11:06am

That also means, no updates from BE's desk clear-out. A blessing in disguise if you ask me.

Deep Breath everyone... @IK - Royal Horticultural Society? ROR please!

ratio of equity to risk weighed assets. whole issue with Metro was that they miscalculated risk weighted assets

Q1 results this morning -- operating profits down 42 per cent to £21.7m.

mild winter

11:29 am
JP11:29am

No Beast from the East.

JP11:29am

Here's Peel Hunt:

JP11:29am

Q1 IMS –warning on FY profitsQ1 EBIT fell 42% from £37.5m to £21.7m (vs PHe £21m) due to the price reductions through the year and a 12% reduction in number of funerals. The company is now more cautious on FY deaths, expecting a 3% decline, which will reduce PBT by £3-4m. We are reducing our forecast by 8% to £41.5m but leave 2020E unchanged at £43m on the assumption that the death rate normalises. Profits in Funerals fell by 34% and Crematoria by 16% combined with an increase in central costs. The averagefuneral price fell from £2,973 last year to £2,904 in Q1, but the company’s FY target of £2,940 is unchanged as the company continues to trial prices. The shares are trading on 10.4x PE 2019E and 9.9x EV/EBITDA. ND:EBITDA is 5.7x. We continue to see considerable risk on pricing as the CMA enquiry continues.

11:29 am
JP11:29am

Number of deaths down sharply:The reduction in deaths in Q1 is not a surprise and the company now expects FY deaths to be 3% lower at 580,000 – this looks reasonable given that the number of deaths in the last 12 months was 578,000. We do not see this reduction as a change in the long-term trends, more a result of a high level of deaths last year and low level this year – we are only adjusting our forecast for 2019.

cracklenpop Any grey on M&S, up today ahead of FY results next week - and poss capital raise update?
wayneJ Incidentally - with IFRS requiring companies to include lease liabilities on their balance sheets - what happens to CET1 for banks? Will the leases of a bank be included as a liability and impact CET1? (Or will the 'right to use asset' offset it - remember that due to the wonders of IFRS they do not perfectly offset each other in any specific year).
Excel Developer Uber IPO draw criticism https://www.ft.com/content/b8c353d8-736c-11e9-bf5c-6eeb837566c5 but here are other loss-making IPOs https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2019/05/10/21/13356204-7016155-image-a-3_1557519719748.jpg
JP11:32am

Argh, technical glitch on the rest of that note. But you get the gist of it.

Tom Dalgleish So maybe funeral discounts gathered pace in anticipation of a mild winter
JP11:33am

PH have a sell, target price is 600p. So still 5 per cent or so to go.

nichoman life insurers been telling us there are more deaths...now dignity saying not enough...who to trust
11:33 am
JP11:33am

Here's Matthew Webb at Panmure:

JP11:34am

Reducing FY19 forecasts on YTDdeath rate, but FY20 unchangedWe reduceour FY19 PBT forecast by 9%, entirely based on the 12% fall in the number of deathsin Q119 and the similar decline in April. However, we see this as another example of the natural variation in deathsrather than a change in the long-term trendand therefore leave our FY20 and FY21 forecasts unchanged. We also note that DTY flagged a slow start to 2019 at its FY18 results in March, and that the UK death numbers are freely available, perhaps explaining the recent share price weakness. We expect the shares to open lower on the FY19 downgrade, but these various points should mitigate the fall.

JP11:34am

Dignity (DTY)has reported a weak Q119, primarilydue to the 12% fall in thenumber of deathsin the period. Q119 revenue was down by 15%. Given the high level of fixed costs in the industry, this resulted in a 42% fallin Q119 underlying operating profit.We assume that the combination of thetough comp (i.e. the high death rate in Q118) and the mild weather caused the lower number of deaths.DTY’s analysis of the historical data suggests that the fall in the number of deaths in January-April is likely to result in a fall in the number of deaths in FY19of 3%or less. We would note that, on the three occasions when the number of deaths has fallen by 10% or more in Q1 (in 1998, 2001 and 2016), the full year decline has been 2% or less. Our new assumption of a3% fall for the full year(previously flat)should therefore,if anything, be conservative. To give an idea of the “worst-case” scenario, the largest full-year decline in the number of deaths in the 1997-2018 period was 4.9%(in 2004).

11:34 am
JP11:35am

Sorry for nasty formatting.

Dec69 - Skeptic @waynej interest us the topic 842 on liabilities as well. US companies that are highly acquisitive are hiding 10X of liabilities on this same IFRS issue.
JP11:35am

Encouragingly, DTY’s market share performance in Q119 was strong in both funerals (+20bps underlying, from 11.6% to 11.8%)and crematoria (+70bps, from 10.6% to 11.3%,helped by the increasingpopularity of direct cremations).Average income per funeral was £2,904in Q119and DTY’s FY19 guidance of £2,940 remains unchanged.We reduce our FY19 underlying operating profit forecast by £3.8m, from £67.3m to £63.5m. This is in line with DTY’s guidance that a 3% fall in the numberof deaths in 2019 could reduce FY19 operating profit by between £3m and £4mversus previous expectations. We leave our FY20 and FY21 forecasts unchanged as there is no reason to think that the number of deaths in those years should be negatively affected by the low levelof deaths YTD in2019.We estimate that DTY remains comfortably above its main covenant, which requires EBITDA to total service to be above 1.5x. This ratio was 2.55x in FY18. We estimate that it will be around 2.1x in FY19 on our new (lower) forecasts

JP11:35am

11:38 am

Saw a request above, not much in my inbox. But there's this chatter from Sam Arie at UBS:

Flaneur (*you're)
wayneJ @Dec69 - US accounts are always copious but often missing in details. '842' is but one issue. The all time classic was Lucent that invented the return on its pension fund.
VV75 spot on by Beyond really
JP11:39am

Is it time to be positive again on Centrica? We think not yet.Centrica shares have fallen 19% since FY 2018 results in February, making Centrica the worst performer in the sector year to date [see Figure 1]. But looking at the numbers, we believe the correction is justified: we now see adjusted cash flow in 2019 coming well below management's target of £2.1–2.3bn. Planned disposals will help, 2020 cashflow looks a little better, and an upside case is still possible. Yet much still hangs on the pension review and nuclear disposal, where downsides could materialise too. We remain Neutral, after cutting PT to 110p.

JP11:40am

What could be the upside case from here?Centrica since 2016 has been chasing its own tail: managing for cash and seeking to avoid the rating downgrade which finally came last week. But the company has been reported in the past as a possible acquisition target ("the question I get often, is one of the oil majors going to buy us or is Amazon going to buy us?", CEO Q&A, H1 2018"). We think an acquisition scenario is not impossible [and so could be a plausible upside case] since being part of a larger company might bring much needed financial flexibility, relieving pressure on credit ratings and dividends and allowing CNA to focus on rebuilding the earnings power of the business.

11:40 am
JP11:40am

What could be the downside case from here?On the other hand, key uncertainties remain: [i] how will the retail business perform post tariff cap [attrition was 6% last year, we assume 4% in 2019, but this could be optimistic]; [ii] what pension deficit will result from the tri-annual review [we assume £1.2bn, but a higher number is possible]; [iii] could there be a deeper than expected dividend cut? We assume a cut from 12p to 6p this year, but a dividend suspension is also not impossible in our view. A 1 to 2 year dividend suspension [as implemented e.g. by RWE in 2016-17] could see the shares fall below £1

FATDAZ @nichoman re-deaths yes I referred to life expectancy figures for UK when I saw those Dignity Comments
JP11:41am

Valuation: £1.10Our valuation is based on a SOTP approach updated for 2018A and comes broadly in line with our c18% cut to 2019-21e EPS (see page 6 for details). In the upside case, if operating performance, the nuclear disposal and the pension review surprise positively, the shares could rise to £1.35. A takeover bid could be another upside case. Or, in the downside case, with weak performance in 2019; a negative surprise on the pension review; and a dividend suspension; the shares could fall to £0.90. We remain Neutral.

"Amazon is going to buy us" - generic bull case for all stocks

Back to Uber, here's Richard Windsor of Radio Free Mobile:

JP11:59am

Uber’s IPO turned from a celebration into a wake as the public market refused to support a valuation that does not reflect the harsh reality of Uber’s outlook.
Lyft was also not spared which fell another 7.4% bringing total losses since its IPO to a thumping 27%.
Uber sold shares at $45 which immediately fell to $42 following listing.
The banks which offer shares on a company’s behalf to investors are also often contracted as part of their service to support the shares following the listing in order to ensure an orderly aftermarket.
It looks like that immediately after trading opened, the listing banks stepped in to support the offering, but that this did not last long.
As soon as support with withdrawn the shares found their true level closing 7.6% down on the day.
This is in stark contrast to Pinterest which rallied very nicely on its first day of trading and has held its valuation for the last month or so.
Pinterest came at a much more reasonable valuation and its business proposition is fairly unique, unlike ride-sharing.

A. M. @BornCynic: well, that's what intermissions are for.
wayneJ @Dec69 - I am finding that Uber frequently cancels on me when I want to go to the outer suburbs. Increasingly unreliable and more expensive.
11:59 am
JP11:59am

The problem here is not that Uber and Lyft are bad companies.
On the contrary, they are pretty well run and are leading a shake-up in how transportation is being bought and sold.
They may well also have a profound impact on autonomous driving when it becomes reality.
The problem is that they are currently engaged in a life or death struggle to become the dominant ridesharing platform in the USA.
Ride-sharing companies are marketplaces where the only barrier to entry is scale.
Consequently, each is vying to become the “go to” place to sell one’s services as a rider or to purchase a ride.
When one becomes the “go to” place to affect a transaction, one can monetise both ends as both sellers and buyers will pay a higher price to do the transaction on that marketplace.
This is when marketplaces become cash generation machines.
Typically, this will occur when one company has either 60% market share or is double the size of its nearest competitor.
In early 2017, it looked like Lyft’s goose was cooked but a series of high-profile slip-ups by Uber absorbed so much management attention that Lyft was given a chance.
In combination with backing from Google, Lyft made the most of this opportunity, leading to two very well financed companies fighting tooth and nail for market dominance.
This means that the outlook for these companies to start generating cash (which the market requires to have a valuation greater than $0) is very poor indeed.
It is this reality combined with the very high valuations at which they have been listed that is putting the pressure on these companies.
There is no sign of this abating and the maiden sets of results are certain to be awash with yet more red ink.
Until this fight is settled, there is very little reason to invest in either company as while they slug it out rock bottom prices and incentives for drivers will continue to plague profitability.
Uber is in the best position to win but I think investors will have a chance to pick it up at levels well below where we are today.
